item.title: Report E-2025060303
item.description:
Report E-2025060303

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-22T01:13:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-11
  • City: GREENCASTLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A. DUIE PYLE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The forklift driver was consolidating freight into a trailer in preparation for transport to its destination facility. As the freight was being moved, the operator pushed the pallet into a piece of debris from a pallet on the ground which pushed into the pallet in front of it causing the unintentional release of corrosive liquid. Immediate action was taken by hazwoper personnel to limit the quantity of spilled liquid. The liquid was cleaned up with the use of absorbents and placed in an overpack container with the damaged box in a separate overpack container in preparation for disposition.

item.title: Report E-2025060153
item.description:
Report E-2025060153

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-22T01:13:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-06
  • City: YORK
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-2ft area of the concrete dock floor and estimated that twenty-five (25) gallons of material were released due to a puncture in one (1) 330-gallon poly tote. Hepaco personnel began the tote transfer and transferred eight hundred (800) liters of material. The damaged tote was cut up and placed into poly containers. The contaminated area was decontaminated, neutralized, and cleaned. The generated waste consists of five (5) 55-gallon poly drums containing impacted debris, absorbents, and cut-up tote pieces. All waste was staged onsite at bay 34. The contractor checked out with ESTES terminal employee Shane Smith. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: As a dockworker was unloading a trailer, he noticed that pallets were double stacked in front of the hazmat shipment. There was no dunnage used to separate the stacked pallet from the hazmat. As the shipment rode to its destination, the movement of the trailer caused the pallet to dig into the hazmat bags and rip them. The damaged bags were removed and placed in a plastic overpack container. All other spilled materials were cleaned up and placed in an overpack containers in preparation for disposition.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 10ft-by-40ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that five to ten (5-10) gallons of material was released due to forklift damaging one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. Clean Harbors deployed granular absorbents to the affected area of the trailer floor. The contractor overpacked the damaged drum into one (1) 65-gallon metal drum. The granular absorbents were gathered and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon metal drums. Clean Harbors labeled the containers and staged the generated waste before they demobilized. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: On May 23, 2025, one (1) 330-gallon tote of E-Pure MSA (UN3265) was punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) ounces of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lewis Environmental Group (LEG) to remediate the impacted site. The crew conducted a tote transfer into one (1) new 330-gallon tote for continued shipment, then dismantled the damaged tote for disposal. LEG personnel utilized granular absorbents, absorbent pads, cleaning agents, and hand tools to remediate the site. The dismantled tote and all impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.description:
Report X-2025052119

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-22T01:13:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-22
  • City: CARLISLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Bryan Youtzy, 042 Operations Supervisor, contacted Safety regarding multiple hazard class spills on the trailer floor. Bryan Youtzy advised the spill appears to be caused by improper loading. Bryan Youtzy stated the freight was loaded on bars of the bulkhead and the freight slid forward while in-tra nsit. Bryan Youtzy advised due to the spill on the trailer floor and the freight being loaded on the bars, he's unable to locate the pros spilling. Bryan Youtzy advised the spill on the trailer wall as well. Safety reviewed what pros are loaded on the trailer and approximately 19 hazardous pros of S igma-Aldrich are loaded within the trailer. Safety advised Bryan Youtzy that CURA will be contacted for remediation. Safety contacted Cameron Kerr with CURA for remediation. FCE personnel noted six (6) damaged one-gallon jugs of UN1789 with approximately one gallon of product released to the trailer floor. An on-site RLC forklift was utilized to unload the trailer onto a poly sheeting staging area for better access to the spill. Crews utilized cleaners and absorbent pads to remove all free-standing product. The damaged jugs, all UN1789 impacted materials, and spent absorbents were collected an d containerized into three (3) 55-gallon drums and five (5) five-gallon pails for disposal. The drums were properly labeled and staged on-site for further management.

  • Description: At 0116 EDT on 5/3, XPO-XCA contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 1 cup of "Benzoyl Chloride" from a 55-gal poly drum onto the trailer and dock floors. The drum was loaded with a faulty seal and is spilling in motion. XPO personnel cannot handle the class 8 material. ERTS will dispatch a contractor to assist. ERTS reported the spill to Chemtrec and spoke to Alan who provided report number: 2025050300007. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-cup of UN1736 Benzoyl Chloride product released to the top and sides of the poly drum impacting area 2’x2’ area due to improper packaging – bad seal on the bung cap. The contractors replaced the bung cap with a new one, and did a shake test. The crew removed the shrink wrap off the drum and wiped it down. (1) 55-poly drum was generated containing impacted PPE, absorbent rags, and shrink wrap. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
